justification: “In the broken toy paradigm (Cole et al. 1992) a child believes they have broken an adult's favourite toy. Infants display more guilt and shame …” – showing that the paradigm is used to elicit and measure guilt.
“In adolescence, moral emotions of guilt and fairness have been frequently studied with economic games, specifically the Dictator, Trust, and Ultimatum Games (DG, UG, TG).”
The same sentence notes that fairness, like guilt, is investigated using these economic games in adolescents.
“According to the Fehr-Schmidt inequity aversion model, two parameters govern the utility …” – indicating the model operationalises and quantifies inequity aversion.
“The prosocial learning task captures how we learn to help others (Lockwood et al. 2016).” Empathy is linked to performance on this task in later paragraphs.
“…when they weigh pain to themselves and others (Crockett et al. 2015; 2017).” These studies use the harm-aversion task to measure sensitivity to harming others.
“Most developmental studies on moral character have focused on learning whom to trust in an iterative version of the TG…” – identifying the Trust Game as the instrument.

“A typical TPP paradigm involves three parties… The third party observes this interaction and is then given the chance to punish the perpetrator…” – describing the paradigm as the measure of punitive moral behaviour.
